Award.AwardTitle: The accumulation of reproductive isolation in a diverse genus of fish (Percidae: Etheostoma)
Award.AbstractNarration: Biological diversity in any given community is maintained by reproductive barriers, or factors that prevent interbreeding between species. Multiple, distinct reproductive barriers may prevent interbreeding between species and a central question concerns the chronological order in which these different barriers evolve. Theory predicts that behavioral isolation, or the absence of interbreeding due to differences in courtship behavior, will be the first reproductive barrier to evolve among populations characterized by the strong action of sexual selection. Through the co-evolution of male courtship traits and female preferences, females are predicted to recognize only the courtship traits of males of their own species. Few studies test this prediction directly and evidence that sexual selection plays a primary role in the origin of species remains largely indirect. Darters are a colorful group of North American freshwater fish with diverse and highly exaggerated male courtship signals and this project quantifies the relative rates of evolution of different reproductive barriers and tests, in particular, whether behavioral isolation evolves earliest. Results will provide one of the few direct tests of the fundamental hypothesis that sexual selection drives the origin of species through the co-evolution of male signals and female preferences. Training of undergraduate and graduate students from groups underrepresented in advanced biology is integral to the project. Results will also be presented to area secondary schools, specifically targeting schools with a high representation of minorities and underprivileged students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The southeastern United States boasts some of the most spectacular biological diversity on the planet, providing a natural laboratory for investigating the causes of evolutionary diversification. “Darters” are a diverse group of freshwater fishes endemic to the eastern U.S. with most species found in the shallow, mid-elevation streams of the southeast. Because darters tend to prefer shallow water, deep river channels can form a difficult barrier to dispersal. These geographic barriers allow for independent evolution in geographically isolated populations, eventually leading to new species in a process called speciation. This project tested whether and how sexual selection—evolution due to competition for mates—contributes to speciation.

 

Most species of darters exhibit elaborate mating ornaments, usually in the form of beautiful breeding colors that rival those of coral reef fishes. Only males express these colors, only during the breeding season, and each species is characterized by a unique color pattern. Elaborate male colors in darters are thought to have arisen due to sexual selection by female preferences, with females always preferring the most elaborate males. The PI thus hypothesized that differences in color pattern among species have arisen due to female preferences acting in divergent directions in geographically isolated populations. If this is the primary cause of speciation, then female preference for her own species’ color patterns should be the strongest barrier to reproduction between species. This project tested that hypothesis and found evidence that supports it and, in addition, found evidence that indicates specific ways in which the hypothesis should be modified.

 

Results demonstrate that: 1) the strength of choosiness and competitiveness is not fixed in a population but depends on the sex ratio, 2) females of at least two species do prefer the color and pattern of males of their own species, 3) behavioral barriers to reproduction are stronger than habitat differences or gametic or genetic incompatibilities, 4) epigenetic differences better predict the strength of behavioral barriers to reproduction than do genetic differences, 5) the color blue was probably present in the ancestor of darters and then subsequently lost in some species, whereas red has been independently gained in many species, 6) the presence of predators predicts whether males of a given darter species will be colorful, but ecological variables do not predict which color the species will be, and, importantly, 7) males have as strong or stronger preferences for mates of their own species as compared to females, 8) males have as strong or stronger preferences for the color patterns of their own species as compared to females, and 9) males are more likely to attack males of another species when that species is similarly colored. These last three results suggest that sexual selection by female choice may not be the only mechanism driving evolutionary divergence and keeping species from interbreeding. Future studies will address the role of male choice and male competition in sexual selection and speciation.
